I'm refreshing my math skills 5 years out of highschool. I've long wanted to get into higher maths but had some gaps in my understanding highschool subjects. This lesson has exposed my biggest deficiency thus far and I'm happy I've found an area to improve. It's a step in the right direction.  Thank you Dave for this content. It's very succinct and easy to digest compared to the typical classroom form.

Thank you for always giving explanations as to why certain steps are done! Most people I've been taught by didn't do that, but I find it exceptionally useful because that's one way in which my mind works: if I don't have an explanation as to why something is done a certain way, it can be really confusing, because then I don't see how to get the same answer myself. I really appreciate your work, thank you again!

COMPREHENSION #4 SOLUTION 3x^2 - 2x - 1 = 0 ∴ 3x^2 - 2x = 1 Divide everything by 3 to get x^2 on it's own: x^2 - (2/3)*x = 1/3 Half of 2/3 quantity squared = 1/3 * 1/3 = 1/9, to be added to both sides. x^2 - (2/3)*x + 1/9 = 1/3 + 1/9 = 3/9 + 1/9 = 4/9 Express the trinomial on the left as a binomial squared, using the 1/3 from 2 lines above as the 2nd term in the binomial: (x - 1/3)^2 = 4/9 ∴ x - 1/3 = √(4/9) = √4/√9 = ±2/±3 ∴ x = ±2/±3 + 1/3 We can ignore ±3 and just use positive 3, because that just changes the sign (±) of the fraction and we are doing that anyway by applying ± to the numerator, 2. ∴ x = 2/3 + 1/3 = 1 (ANSWER 1) OR x = -2/3 + 1/3 = -1/3 (ANSWER 2)

COMPREHENSION #3 SOLUTION: 4x^2 + x - 3 = 0 ∴ 4x^2 + x = 3 Which is the same as 4x^2 + 1*x = 3 Divide everything by 4 to get x^2 on it's own: x^2 + (1/4)*x  = 3/4 Half of 1/4 quantity squared = 1/8 * 1/8 = 1/64, to be added to both sides. x^2 + (1/4)*x + 1/64 = 3/4 + 1/64 = 48/64 + 1/64 = 49/64 Express the trinomial on the left as a binomial squared, using the 1/8 from 2 lines above as the 2nd term in the binomial: (x + 1/8)^2 = 49/64 ∴ x + 1/8 = √(49/64) = √49/√64 = ±7/±8 ∴ x = ±7/±8 - 1/8 We can ignore ±8 and just use positive 8, because that just changes the sign (±) of the fraction and we are doing that anyway by applying ± to the numerator, 7. ∴ x = 7/8 - 1/8 = 6/8 = 3/4 (ANSWER 1) OR x = -7/8 - 1/8 = -8/8 =  -1 (ANSWER 2)

It's always going to match the sign of your b-term, from the form of a*x^2 + b*x + c.  The value of -b/a tells you the sum of the two roots, and -b/(2*a) tells you the x-coordinate of the vertex.

If you don't know why, it can be easy to make mistakes when extrapolating the concepts to new and more complex problems. This is true for pretty much everything in life. It's always best to know the "why".

@stupidmonkey151  Yeah, and that's one reason why I've had so much of an issue with math in the past: not one of my teachers would ever take the time to explain "why". Unfortunately in college I'm seeing the same thing, and so I find that I have to take as many notes as possible. I have to include as many examples as possible in my notes, so I can try and see some connections in what's being done.

Uhm, how did half of 1/4 become 1/8? isn't it supposed to be 1/2?? Idk, how halving 1/4 became 1/8 at all...

​ @SCRKT007  "half of 1/4" can be written as "1/2 * 1/4", which can be written as "1*1 / 2*4". So you multiply the 2 numbers on the top together, and multiply the 2 numbers on the bottom together. Which gives 1/8. Or imagine you have a 1 liter bottle of water that is only 1/4 full. If you drink half of that 1/4, it's then only 1/8 full.

@NickHope , why can't we add 3/4 + 1/64  by multiplying 64 by the numerator and denominator of left side fraction and vice versa for the right sided one (the way it was taught by professor dave in "addition and subtraction of fractions" video). really confused

​ @muhammadaunsiddiqui5933  You can do that, which gives 192/256 + 4/256 = 196/256, which can then be simplified to 49/64. But because in this example the least common multiple is equal to the largest denominator (i.e. 64), I did it more quickly by directly expressing 3/4 as a fraction with 64 as the denominator (i.e. 48/64) and then adding it to the 1/64. It often helps to visualize portions of pizza to make sense of this stuff.

Anyways, if you are simply curious: After simplifying the expression you are left with the polynomial 2x^4 - 4x^3 + x^2 - 40 = 0 This 4th degree polynomal has two Real roots: x = -1.77 and x = 2.82 (these are not exact solutions, I solved the polynomial numerically in a graphing calculator)

Maybe you make the same mistake as me, I divided the whole term instead of just the coefficient. Therefore, do not divide (x / 4) / 2 but only (1/4) / 2.
@guersomfalcon7544  and then ? I did it but i am literally stuck

@chiragshah8882  Since you wanna generate a perfect square you need to square the result of the division((1/4)/2) and added to the right and to the left of the equation. Then on the left you will have a perfect square, so just factorize it. The result will be (x+1/8)^2=3/4+1/64, if you solve that you will get x=3/4.
@guersomfalcon7544  after (x+1/8)^2=3/4+1/64, how did you solve to get x=3/4

@johnn522  Then you get (x+1/8)^2 = 49/64, followed by taking the square root, x + 1/8 = sqrt(49/64), the square root of 49/64 = 0.875 or 7/8 so, x + 1/8 = 7/8, minus 1/8 gives you the result of x = 3/4
